title: Reverse factoring proliferates in CIMIC
text:
CIMIC markets reverse factoring via Greensill to its suppliers as "an innovative solution" that optimises suppliers' cash flow by allow them to get their invoices paid early by Greensill for a fee (Greensill collects money from CIMIC at a later date.)

CIMIC tells suppliers that reverse factoring is a "win win" because it improves cash flow and balance sheets, reduces the time suppliers spend on "non-payment admin" and frees up credit lines.

But rating agencies and regulators are wary of reverse factoring schemes, because they allow companies to account for owed invoices under "trade and other payables" on their balance sheets rather than as conventional debt.

This makes it harder for investors to figure out exactly how much money comanies using reverse factoring owe.

While companies can have legitimate reasons for using reverse factoring to manage payments to suppliers, ratings agencies and regulators become concerned when companies use the technique to hide how much debt they owe, or pressure suppliers into accepting discounts on their invoices to get paid within a reasonable period.

CIMIC, which is building billions of dollars of infrastructure projects around Australia including motorways, metros and earthworks for the new Western Sydney Airport, appears to have a strong balance sheet, with the construction group reporting it held $1.37 billion of net cash in the six months ended June 30.

But CIMIC was also carrying $6 billion of trade and other payables (which include its reverse factoring liabilities) at the end of June, up from $5.67 billion six months earlier.

Companies are not required to break out exactly how much of their liabilities have been reversed factored, but accounting firms are starting to pay closer attention and some companies, including UK construction group Balfour Beatty, are abandoning its use altogether to keep their accounts simple and transparent.

The Australian Accounting Standards Board, which is responsible for developing, issuing and maintaining Australian accounting standards, told the Financial Review in late September that it had noted the rising interest in reverse factoring facility disclosures and would be "discussing [the topic] further with the International Accounting Standards Board and other relevant regulators".

Labor shadow minister for small business Brendan O'Connor has also asked the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to formally investigate reverse factoring amid concerns the financing scheme could be a misuse of market power.

Both banks and private financiers like Greensill provide reverse factoring facilities. But while banks will only pay 80 per cent of suppliers' invoices early, Greensill is willing to pay 100 per cent earlier, minus its financier's fee.

The fees are based on an annual interest rate and the number of days an invoice is paid early. Under Greensill's terms, if an interest rate is 9 per cent and the invoice is paid 60 days before the due date, the fee is equivalent to 1.48 per cent of the face value of the invoice. The earlier the supplier wants to get paid, the higher the fee.

Suppliers who want to use Greensill's scheme must also sign an agreement allowing the financier to register "security interests" associated with receiveables transferred on the personal properties securities register.
description: CIMIC is encouraging all its suppliers to pay fees to financier Greensill to get money they are owed by the construction group.
